importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The government shutdown began on October 1, 2025, leading to the cancellation of key CDC scientific participation in the IDWeek conference.
The article was published on October 20, 2025, reporting on the ongoing consequences of the shutdown on public health research and communication.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown period from October 1 to October 20, 2025, disrupted federal scientific operations, including CDC researcher participation in critical public health meetings.

keyTakeAways: The CDC was unable to send researchers to the IDWeek conference in Atlanta due to the government shutdown, which began on October 1, 2025.
The shutdown resulted in federal scientists being unpaid, leading to postponed conference appearances unless funded independently.
Despite being the host city for IDWeek, Atlanta saw a significant absence of CDC scientists, with only about 10 of hundreds of listed speakers being CDC-affiliated and none showing up.
The absence of CDC experts is particularly concerning given surging cases of measles and whooping cough and the emergence of new disease threats like bird flu and superbugs.
The Trump administration’s policies, including funding cuts, layoffs, and restrictions on scientific communication, have undermined public health response capabilities.
CDC scientists like Dr. Anna Yousaf were barred from presenting research on long-term outcomes of pediatric COVID-19 cases, indicating a broader restriction on scientific information sharing.

In response, experts such as Dr. Michael Osterholm are launching open-access publications and forming private collaborations to fill the gap left by the government's reduced role in public health research.
The Infectious Disease Society of America (IDSA) and CDC initially planned close collaboration, but federal policies under HHS have created friction and chilling effects on scientific exchange.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Due to a government shutdown that began on October 1, 2025, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) was unable to send key researchers to the IDWeek conference in Atlanta, the largest annual gathering of infectious disease experts in the U.S. This absence is especially troubling amid surging cases of measles and whooping cough, as well as emerging threats like bird flu and superbugs. The shutdown has also led to unpaid federal scientists, funding cuts, and restrictions on scientific communication, including blocking CDC doctors like Dr. Anna Yousaf from sharing vital research on long-term outcomes of pediatric COVID-19 cases. The Trump administration’s policies, including HHS's restrictions on federal collaboration, have created a chilling effect on public health research. In response, experts like Dr. Michael Osterholm are launching new open-access publications and forming private research collaborations to maintain critical public health information flow.
title: CDC Researchers Skip Key Infectious Disease Conference Amid Government Shutdown
